As of Tuesday morning, Sept. 8, heavy wildfire smoke has partially cleared in Pierce County, but is expected to return later in the day and overnight.

Air quality conditions in most of the Puget Sound region are unhealthy and everyone should take precautions, especially infants, children, and people over 65, or those that are pregnant, have heart or lung diseases (such as asthma or COPD), respiratory infections, diabetes, stroke survivors, and those suffering from COVID-19.

Wildfire smoke is full of small particles that can cause and worsen many health problems such as: asthma attack, chest pain, coughing, fast heartbeat, headaches, irritated sinuses, stinging eyes, and trouble breathing.

You are encouraged to stay inside and away from pollution when air quality levels become unhealthy. Check the air quality forecast regularly at the Puget Sound Clean Air Agency’s website: https://pscleanair.gov/

post_text: When COVID-19 abruptly ended in-person school last March, our educators did everything in their power to make the transition to online learning as seamless and consistent as possible. But it was a new and stressful time, and we had to make the most of a bad situation. It soon became clear that the pandemic wasn’t going anywhere, so district leaders spent the summer working around the clock to ensure that when school started — either online or with a blended learning hybrid model — our students would have access to the best, most rigorous education available. Bethel’s Teaching and Learning Department spent the summer working with teacher leaders to build professional development courses aimed at helping teachers bridge the gap between the traditional classroom and remote learning. Learn more here: https://bit.ly/3lBmSEY

Prior to becoming one of the biggest movie stars in the world, Johnson spent 8 years as a professional wrestler for the World Wrestling Federation (WWF, now WWE). A Shining Mountain Elementary first grader named Jenna was having a hard time with the transition to distance learning. She missed being in school with her classmates, and she missed reading with her teachers. That’s where paraeducator Marissa Jordan stepped in. Marissa knew Jenna needed a little extra attention and reached out to see if she could help. They spent a half hour reading together, talking, and even showing off their cats. It was exactly what Jenna needed, according to her grandmother.

“She had so much fun with it. It meant so much to her to get a little alone time,” she said.

Thank you to Marissa and all the other educators in our district who are going above and beyond to help their students continue to learn and grow.

He regularly pays homage to his homeland and culture of Hawaii.

People like Nadja West, a US Army Lieutenant General and the country’s 44th US Army Surgeon General.

West is the youngest of 12 adopted children — 10 of whom joined the Army — raised by a logistics warrant officer and his journalist-activist wife.

Her father's 33-year career inspired her to join the Army, and her West Pointer brother encouraged her to attend the newly integrated U.S. Military Academy.

West, a career family medicine doctor and dermatologist who boasts airborne and air assault qualifications, became the 44th Army Surgeon General in December 2015. She is the first black female lieutenant general in the Army and the highest-ranking woman to graduate from West Point.

March is Women’s History Month, and we thought we’d use the occasion to celebrate a few of the amazing women who have contributed so much to our country.

Sojourner Truth was an African American abolitionist, women’s rights activist, and author. Born in New York in 1797, Isabella Baumfree (Truth) was first sold at a slave auction when she was 9-years-old for $100, along with a flock of sheep. She was sold two more times before she was 13.

She married and had five children before she finally escaped from slavery in 1826. After the New York Anti-Slavery Law was passed, her five-year old son was illegally sold into slavery. She filed a lawsuit to get him back, and became the first black woman to sue a white man in a United States court and prevail.

In 1843 she changed her name to Sojourner Truth and embarked on a journey to speak out against slavery and oppression. Her activism for the abolitionist movement gained the attention of President Abraham Lincoln, who invited her to the White House in October 1864.

Today is Billy Frank Jr. Day, a National Day of Recognition celebrating the larger-than-life champion of Indian treaty rights and advocate of environmental stewardship.

Frank was the public face and spokesman in a 30-year battle for treaty fishing rights in Washington that eventually led to a 1979 Supreme Court decision. The case (United States v. Washington) upheld tribal rights to half the catch in their traditional waters, and designated them co-managers of the fishery with the state. Following that decision, Frank chaired the Northwest Indian Fisheries Commission for most of the final 30 years of his life.

He was posthumously awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom in 2015, the nation’s highest civilian honor. That same year, Congress voted to rename the Nisqually National Wildlife Refuge in his honor. The refuge is located near the Nisqually Reservation where Frank lived until his death in 2014 at the age of 83.

The Cedarcrest Middle School boys basketball team is playing great this year, but the team’s coach is more impressed with what his players are doing in the classroom than on the court.

Coach Zach Womack said this year’s varsity basketball team is the best he’s ever had. The team is undefeated, and they’ve been beating their opponents by huge margins. But that’s not what has coach Womack so excited about the team.

"We score a lot of points on the court, but we strive to score the highest in the classroom,” he said.

None of the players are failing any of their classes, and Womack says he’s even getting emails from teachers complimenting the boys on how hard they’re working and how much leadership they’re showing in class.

The team squared off against a tough Spanaway Middle School squad on Tuesday. It was a hard fought game that stayed close until halftime, but the Cedarcrest boys pulled away in the third quarter and ended up winning by 30 points.

The team plays Frontier Middle on Friday at 3:30 p.m. at CMS.

post_text: February is Black History Month, and we thought we’d use the occasion to celebrate some of the amazing men and women who have contributed so immensely to this country. This week we’re looking at the extraordinary life and career of Robert Smalls, who escaped slavery and became a successful businessman, newspaper publisher, and member of the U.S. House of Representatives. Smalls was born into slavery in South Carolina in 1839. As a teenager, he developed a love for the sea that eventually helped set him free. When the Civil War began in 1861, Smalls was assigned to steer the CSS Planter, a lightly armed Confederate military transport. After a year on the ship, Smalls freed himself, his crew, and their families by commandeering the vessel and piloting it to Union controlled waters. After his escape, Smalls served in the Union Navy until the end of the war. He later launched several successful businesses, including a transportation company and a newspaper. He capped off his impressive career by twice being elected to the U.S. House of Representatives.

As you know, this is a dark and dangerous time of the year for driving, with increased risks for our students as they travel to and from school. We are only halfway through the school year and we have already had 10 school bus accidents involving cars hitting buses. Fortunately, no students have been hurt so far. Almost all of these crashes were caused by cars running into the back of a bus (and the other was from the side!). In comparison, for all of last year, there were 9 accidents and only 4 the year before that. This upward trend is very concerning. In addition, this year we've had three students hit by cars on their way to school, while walking or riding a bicycle.

Driving requires our full attention at all times. Our 21,000 students going to school each day, often in areas without sidewalks and street lights, deserve everyone's full attention to safety.

This week we’re looking at the life and career of groundbreaking computer scientist Lisa Gelobter. Among a host of other accomplishments, Gelobter helped launch HULU, served as the the Vice President of Black Entertainment Television (BET), and was the Chief Digital Service Officer for the United States Department of Education. Gelobter is also well known for her role in developing a host of internet technologies, including Shockwave Flash and animated GIFS. post_text: February is Black History Month, and we thought we’d use the occasion to celebrate some of the amazing men and women who contributed so immensely to this country. We’re starting out with inventor Lewis Latimer, who put his stamp on everything from telephones to light bulbs to toilets on trains. Latimer was born in 1848, the son of runaway slaves who escaped to Massachusetts. After serving in the U.S. Navy during the Civil War, Latimer took a job in a Boston patent office. Later, while working as a draftsman for Alexander Graham Bell, Latimer made the drawings required for a patent for Bell’s telephone. A genius inventor himself, Latimer first came up with a new toilet system to be used on railroad cars, and later invented the first light bulb with a carbon filament, which was a vast improvement from the paper filament used in Thomas Edison's original light bulb. For all his work, Latimer was inducted into the National Inventors Hall of Fame.

Congratulations to Raith Antonio on being named this month’s Native American Education Program Student of the Month.

Raith is a member of the Laguna Pueblo Tribe of New Mexico, and one of the things he loves about the Native American Program is getting to know members of other tribes.

“The main thing I enjoy about the Native American Program is meeting others and learning about each other as well as making friends. Admittedly some will regard it as awkward at first, but that's the fun of it, with a little awkwardness and laughter many friends are often made,” he said.

The SLHS sophomore is a member of his school’s JROTC program, where he performs with the color guard and the drill team.

One of the things he’s excited about is teaching more people about about his own tribe.

“I would like to teach others about how my tribe was actually able to survive extremely well in the harsh New Mexico desert,” he said.
